content.question: An object rotates with an angular speed that varies with time, as shown in the graph. How can the graph be used to determine the magnitude of the angular acceleration <math alttext="a" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>α</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the object? Justify your selection.

choices.label: Subtract the greatest value of the angular speed from the smallest value of the angular speed, because <math alttext="a equals delta omega" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>α</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mo>=</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Determine the slope of the line from <math alttext="0 second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="2 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, because the slope represents <math alttext="the fraction delta omega over delta t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>ω</mi></mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Determine the area bounded by the line and the horizontal axis from <math alttext="0 second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="2 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, because <math alttext="alpha equals one half omega delta t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mi>α</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mo>=</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mi>ω</mi><mi>Δ</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.
The angular acceleration cannot be determined without knowing the rotational inertia of the object.

content.answer: Determine the slope of the line from <math alttext="0 second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="2 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, because the slope represents <math alttext="the fraction delta omega over delta t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>ω</mi></mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>.

skill.text: 3.B: Apply an appropriate law, definition, theoretical relationship, or model to make a claim.
